reviews.review_title: They should make this into a series!
reviews.content:
Great movie. I grew up in the system and think they did a decent job showing the struggles of the system.
It really would make a great series.

reviews.review_title: An emotional journey that leaves you wanting more
reviews.content: Short Term 12 is a movie that has the power to influence you emotionally. For one, the narrative revolves around young adults who supervise a foster care facility. A different spin on the coming-of-age genre opens up different opportunities. Secondly, every single resident at the facility is relatable from one angle or another. We didn't get to explore their stories as it doesn't completely revolve around them but you just wish you knew a bit more about them. And lastly, the subject of past trauma can make you heartsick. Sometimes even despondent but Grace's emotional support to the resident provides the needed enthusiasm that doesn't let the heart grow cold. Even though she's the one struggling with past trauma, she doesn't give up on the kids.This movie featured several actors that would appear in cinema or publications in the future. Just two years after Short Term 12 was released, Rami Malek, who played Nate, got to star in Mr. Robot, a personal favorite of mine in the 2010s. Grace was played by Brie Larson, who got to join Marvel Cinematic Universe as Captain Marvel. She was also starred in Room (2015), which is rated really high, but I'm yet to watch that movie. The third actress that I want to mention is Kaitlyn Dever. She played Jayden, the tough but frail girl with a history of harming herself, and she also starred in one of my favorite comedies in the recent past - Booksmart (2019). One thing that I like about watching a lot of movies is seeing some familiar faces from time to time. I know these three actors from movies of completely different backgrounds and seeing them interact in such circumstances, under such roles, and just seeing a different angle of their talent as actors were pleasant for my viewing experience.Even though I liked this film a lot, it fails in comparison to other coming-of-age movies and even some of my favorite dramas. The biggest strengths here are the acting and the use of tools to bring out a huge emotional response but it's a bit weaker in storytelling and the pace. It was a bit difficult what kind of story is being told here as it was mostly revolving around personal problems that Grace is dealing with and how the foster house residents remind her of the demons that haunt her past. To me, it sometimes felt that every sequence in the territory of the foster home was fascinating to some extent but every shot that was taken outside of it just didn't have enough charm to keep it interesting. I don't know whether this is the result of using the angle of young adults instead of the kids at the foster home or just the lack of scenes that are worth remembering or maybe even the fact that the most important scenes of the film, the ones that are supposed to have the highest impact, are a bit underwhelming. My favorite scenes here would include the rap by Marcus, the story by Jayden, and the stories at the beginning and end of the movie, Mason just has a knack for storytelling and I love it. The underwhelming scenes here would include the one where they smash the car with a baseball ball, Grace and Mason falling out because of Grace being afraid to open up, and, I guess, Jayden's violent tantrum after her father fails to pick her up from the facility. That sequence was really strong and acted well but I just felt awkward when watching it, it was uneasy to experience that.Overall, I'd still say I like it. It wasn't as impactful as The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012), a movie that also dealt with past traumas, or Frances Ha (2012), a movie that dealt with someone desperately trying to hold on to her past, but it still stood out and gave me a warm fuzzy feeling when viewing. Those two movies are among my favorites of the genre in the 2010s and I don't dare to say that anything worse than them is automatically bad. Usually, I'm a bit discouraged when films are too long but here, I kind of wished it was longer so we would get to see more of the kinds, maybe having a bigger ending or maybe looking into what's hurting the other residents in the foster house. I just felt like I wanted more and this movie had more to deliver but just didn't share it, at least it felt like that. But besides that, I'm happy with what I've got.

This movie clings in the "Best Picture Of The Year" list! The only reason that it's not is simply because if it won, it would turn the movie industry upside down. Imagine: A low budget movie with a great story and fantastic acting. No Way! Watch and enjoy this for the long Term!

Well, I am rarely lost for words but I barely know where to start but this is phenomenal. It starts slowly and although there is not a story in a traditional sense as time goes on each individual's story builds until the crescendo towards the end. The acting is phenomenal with Brie Larson as the figurehead who pulls in an amazing performance. Its funny, heartbreaking and philosophical. Stunning.

I first found this movie as part of a training for my work as I have been a residential counselor/child care worker for over a decade now and this movie was part of a required training to point out all that they did wrong. Great movie though and almost hits what we do on the head. The job is fairly unknown to the outside world but this movie really got a lot right. Sad it's not more known and praised as it speaks volumes and now has 2 academy award winners in it. LaKieth should really be included in that for this performance alone. I worked with a lot of troubled kids, having my own trauma as well and the movie really touches on that dynamic. All the actors truly shine.

reviews.review_title: Fantastic underrated movie with a solid Brie Larson performance
reviews.content: This movie is hands down one of the best movies of the year , a very powerful heartwarming writing and a great acting that makes this movie easily one of the best. The story is based on true facts that really can happen in this world to show us how hard the life can be. and the performance Brie Larson did in this movie is Fantastic it really brought her character (Grace) to life. and with a solid acting like that the story keeps you emotionally attached to those poor kids lives. The entire cast has given a brilliant performance, but it's Brie Larson who impresses the most as Grace and the film manages to portray her toughness & fragility evocatively. The locations are very lifelike, the entire film has a very calm & relaxed atmosphere for which the shooting location is responsible for, editing is finely done & it is smartly written & directed. On an overall scale, Short Term 12 is one of those dramas that are heartwarming & heartbreaking at the same time that will have you go through every emotion you're capable of and dares to deal with issues most people or families aren't very comfortable viewing or discussing about. If you didn't watch Short term 12 yet and you're looking for a heartwarming and inspiring than you better watch :) ..!!

This movie is good, not Oscar good but the performances are Oscar worthy.
Brie Larson, I was not familiar with her work before this film and I must say the whole time I was watching her I was thinking this is the new Meryl Streep. She give a very powerful performance.
John Gallagher is better than average as Bries boyfriend. If he is half as nice off the screen as he was on it he should father a lot of kids!
This story is not new. Troubled teens and staff at a Short Term Foster Care Facility. In fact this movie could very easily be a After School Special movie from 1985 if not for the new millennium upgrade on all the kids/staffs troubles.
I am writing this review a week after watching this film and I cannot remember how it ends. Maybe it's me.
That being said this 7 movie gets a 8 from me for the performances of the two leads.

reviews.review_title: It is worth watching at least for the sake of the octopus!
reviews.content: The first thing that delighted me was the adults. This happens extremely rarely... Even in the movies. Their attitude, behavior and reaction to sometimes disturbing actions and provocations on the part of teenagers. Being able to react calmly and find a way out of any situation is worth a lot, I know for myself... The film tells about the most important thing. About love and patience for those for whom you are responsible.The story about an octopus and a shark, told by one of the heroines, deserves no less attention. It would be worth thinking about...

I got 25 minutes into this film before giving up: I could only make out 10% of the dialogue. Maybe this is to be expected of a low-budget film - probably using amateur actors - but the lead parts appear to have been given to professionally-trained actors who have not troubled to learn to speak properly!I rate the film 2 instead of 1 out of 10 as visually it looked as though the actors are convincing in their roles. Grace (Brie Larson) and Mason (John Gallagher) looked to to be well-cast, and the chemistry between them was apparent. But I'm not going to waste my time guessing at a plot when the actors mumble or garble their lines. Films should be consumer-tested for audibility and released with subtitles if the actors/sound recording team have not done their work properly.

Short Term 12 did a great job of encompassing everything in its hour and thirty minutes of runtime. I didn't feel like anything was left out, nor unnecessary. There were details and close ups of how time passes in the facility, as well as outbursts. It shows how the workers manage to keep their calm throughout chaos, how much will and persistence they have in helping those teenagers; how accustomed they've grown to it. The workers went through similar things as some of the teenagers there, so they know how horrifying that is. That's why they're helping them and providing them with a safe place to be. A lot of the teenagers aren't just saddened and willing to accept help - they lash out at others and themselves. They're filled with rage and confusion because of being raised in households where there was violence and abuse. They associate love to manipulation. They developed illnesses because of it. It makes me so sad that people are cruel to children. The workers are very compassionate towards the teenagers, they don't force anything onto them, try to make them happy or "fix" them. They're simply there for them, they keep things in order and provide them care. Thats's something every young person needs and deserves. The movie shows how Grace is still recovering from her adolescence and coping with it. She has trust issues with Mason and her pregnancy brings negative associations from the past with it. Her dad is coming out of prison in a week. She empathizes with the teenagers, especially the new girl who comes into the facility. Lots of the teenagers are very talented and artistic. When the new girl read a children's story to Grace, I was struck with grief. My eyes filled with tears numerous times throughout the movie. I'm glad the beginning and end have great and funny stories. The relationship between Grace and Mason is really nice, and intimate. Overall, the ambiance is quiet but powerful and it's a very significant topic. I'd recommend this movie to everyone. It'll shake you up or if anything, it'll show you the world of teenagers who have experienced abuse and their treatment. And I'm guessing those who have experienced such things will be able to resonate with it. (I watched it because I saw that someone who has, loves it.)
Really boring movie. Should've watched a different movie tonight.

It all could have been painfully mawkish, populated as it is with the kinds of kids who provide inspiration for after-school specials. Instead, "Short Term 12" comes from a place of delicate and truthful understatement, which allows the humanity and decency of its characters—and, yes, the lessons—to shine through naturally. The film's originality begins with the setting: a foster-care center for at-risk teens whose troubles run the gamut from depression to substance abuse to self-mutilation. Writer- director Destin Daniel Cretton based "Short Term 12" partly on his own experiences working at such a center, and previously made a short film on the subject. In drawing the story out to feature length, Cretton takes an abidingly naturalistic, conversational approach to both the complicated issues these kids face and the no-nonsense way their counselors try to help them. Chief among them is Brie Larson as the twenty-something Grace, a formerly troubled teen herself who now hopes to serve as a guide for others. Just as the extent of Grace's painful past is revealed to us in deliberate pieces, Larson's performance itself is a revelation. It's a welcome and long-overdue lead role for the actress who's been so engaging in supporting parts in films like "The Spectacular Now" and "Scott Pilgrim vs. The World" and the Showtime series "The United States of Tara." There's a directness about her that's appealing, even here where she's meant to look a little mousy and low-key. At the film's start, Grace seems to have achieved a comfortable balance between her professional and personal lives. She handles both the mundane routine of the place and the volatile emotional flare-ups with the same sort of cool confidence. She also has a loving, playful relationship with her longtime live-in boyfriend, the shaggy, foulmouthed Mason (played amiably by John Gallagher Jr.), who works alongside her as a supervisor at the center. But the impending departure of one kid and the arrival of another shake everything up for her. Tough, intense Marcus (Keith Stanfield) is about to turn 18, which means he'll have to leave the home; frightened to make his way on his own, he acts out during these final days instead of facing his future. A profane and deeply felt rap song he wrote details his life of neglect and abuse, and the fact that Cretton presents the performance in one long take adds to its power. Marcus overlaps briefly with the surly and withdrawn new girl, Jayden (Kaitlyn Dever), who insists her father is coming to get her soon so she refuses to make friends. One of the subtle beauties of "Short Term 12" is the way it intimately depicts how the counselors find ways into these kids' lives and connect with them. For Grace and Jayden, it's through a shared love of drawing. But Jayden also uses her art to reveal the truth about her home life, which stirs secrets within Grace that she'd fought hard for years to suppress. This upheaval comes at a time when Grace and Mason are trying to create something lasting for themselves: a home and a family of their own. The ambivalence Grace finds herself feeling, and the way that emotional shift shatters Mason, are both believable and heartbreaking. Cretton shows as much care and kindness with the minutiae of the daily routine—the doling out of meds, searches for contraband and forced recreational activities like Wiffle ball games —as he does with the larger issues that plague these lives in flux. He also infuses his story with unexpected humor as the kids hassle each other—and their supervisors—on the road to healing. While some of the third-act choices his characters make seem a little extreme compared to the realism that marks the rest of the film, Cretton consistently refrains from employing a tone that's heavy-handed. "Short Term 12" is a small gem in which the uplift feels earned rather than preached.

reviews.review_title: Stays grounded in the cold reality of its story but keeps a warm heart.
reviews.content: Brilliantly uses art to indirectly express the kids' deepest, darkest emotions. We bear witness to their fears and loss and pain through creative outpourings that remain unique and never become melodramatic. Bree Larson captures the emotional reality of the lead character. And the supporting cast is brilliant throughout. A small film that will make you believe that maybe there are some superheroes in the world.

This movie was incredible! The dialogs, the drama, the storyline, characters, everything! It was entertaining until the credits rolled. Brie Larson and John Gallagher Jr were terrific! The problems and the situations were a bit out there, but you know that stuff like that probably happens. I thought it was raw, real, and sharp. The emotions that arose in me while watching this were really overwhelming at times and I also thought the children played their roles really well. I tried to find something that I didn't like about this movie but I honestly couldn't. This definitely should have been up for some academy's/golden globes and I was really surprised that it wasn't even nominated. I know that it killed in the festivals, but wow. Just a great movie. If you had any hesitation about whether or not to see this, I promise you, it is not a waste of your time.

This was a seriously refreshing movie to watch.Sad thing is,No one I met has seen or even heard about it.Blame it on poor marketing.This movie is about the teenagers of a foster-care facility and the caretakers themselves. How they affect each other and themselves in the process can be seen here. Brie Larson is just terrific in this. Perhaps her best performance yet.Another standout is Kaitlyn Denver.She is young and talented and plays the role of a troubled teenager.All the kids and teenagers were interesting. The chemistry between them is clearly visible especially between Brie and Kaitlyn. Every character undergoes through mental stress in this film and its a treat to watch them tackle it and come out stronger than before."What doesn't kill you make you stronger " literally ; applies here .The Rap song scene was truly great and is still fresh in my mind months after seeing this.In the end, you will feel good about life after watching this. Feel Good guaranteed.

reviews.review_title: Honest, Sincere, Moving and Uplifting...a great, great movie
reviews.content: Holy Crap! What a great movie this is. A movie that has so much heart hasn't come by in a long, long while. Gravity, American Hustle and all the other hyped up movies in contention for this year's Oscar pale in comparison to this movie. (Seriously...what the hell was so good about American Hustle anyway???)A great script, some very real performances, amazing screenplay and perfect direction make this movie an instant classic. It will be etched in my mind forever.Brie Larson, as Grace is exceptional and John Gallagher Jr. (of Newsroom) is extremely talented and right on the money as Mason. Kaitlyn Dever turns in a mature performance for a 17 year old and Keith Stanfield plays the subdued Marcus to a tee. A must watch movie and easily one of the best, if not the best movie of the year.

Being a huge fan of Brie Larson, I was incredibly excited for Short Term 12. I have to say, not only did it meet my expectations but it completely surpassed them.Short Term 12 is based on the 2008 short of the same name, which I have not seen. I knew roughly what to expect after watching the trailer, but I had the worry that perhaps the trailer showed too much of the movie and I wouldn't be as engaged as I possibly could. I needn't have worried at all, Short Term 12 is captivating and excellently written. Even with the short 96 minute run time, we get HUGE amounts of character development, more than many 150 minute movies have. The character building is so good that you feel as though you know these characters and enjoy hanging out with them.These complex characters would be nothing without good actors to play them, but thankfully the cast of Short Term 12 isn't just good, it's outstanding. There are some incredible supporting roles from very young actors like Keith Stanfield and Katylin Dever, both of whom's story lines are very genuine and well written. In the more major roles we have Rami Malek and John Gallagher Jr, who are both excellent in their roles, But of course, the star of the show is the incredible Brie Larson. Short Term 12 doesn't seem to be receiving much awards attention which is a shame, as Brie Larson deserves so much more recognition and every leading actress award there is. She delivers a stunning performance cementing her as one of the best actresses in the business, she gives a performance that's easily one of, if not the, best of 2013.Destin Cretton directs Short Term 12 and does a brilliant job of doing so. The cinematography is beautiful and there is so much raw emotion that the movie doesn't need to rely on sad music to make you feel emotional, it manages to do it with the incredible acting, writing and directing. Short Term 12 is a roller-coaster ride of emotions, it will make you feel sad, happy, depressed and uplifted. It's a true tour de force of cinema, and is my favourite movie of 2013.
A beautiful, emotional rollercoaster. A great original look at some of today's best acting talents, great film.

Rarely do I write reviews, but this film is definitely deserving of one. On the surface this seems like a story line you've seen before. I can assure you that you've never seen it done this well. While most films dealing with abused children try to over explain the characters, this one does not. It gives you just enough to look at the screen and see people instead of characters. It's really hard to explain the emotions this movie made me feel without ruining it for you. If anything, watch it for an extremely powerful performance from Brie Larson. She's going to be a huge deal in just a few short years. You'll want to be able to reference this as a film where you knew she'd be a big actress.
I loved the happy and endearing moments. Everyone should watch this, to get a deeper understanding of life.

reviews.review_title: A very Intimate and Heartbreaking Look into the Lives of People who have been Damaged.
reviews.content:
This movie immediately drew my attention when I read the summary. My own mother has worked in a similar institute, and I was always curious how one keeps up with those situations on a day-to-day basis. When I finished watching, I was in awe. This movie is very powerful and full of love and heartbreak, and deserves a very high amount of praise.Acting:
Brie Larson always has been a tough actress for me to judge. She can be incredibly subtle and professional with the right role, but also very flat and stoic with the wrong one. This is one of the better ones. It is not uncommon for coworkers at such an institute to have come from a similar background as the kids they are looking after, and the more the movie progresses, the more you want to find out what happened to this young woman. How does one who is so full of compassion and understanding and wisdom unable and afraid to open up about herself and follow her own lessons in life? Brie sells every likable aspect about this character excellently, and convinces you just how much respect these kind of people deserve for doing their job right.John Gallager Jr is even better; not necessarily in terms of acting, but his character is an absolute joy to watch. He radiates professionalism, friendliness, warmth and love all at once, while not being perfect all the same. John himself does a terrific job at giving life to all these aspects, and watching him interact with Brie is wonderful.Katlyn Denver as Jayden is a gem. While she carries often the same sullen expression in a lot of her roles, this character fits that attitude perfectly. Once you slowy discover what she struggles with everyday, you feel a great amount of empathy for her, and when this gets the better of her, it is absolutely heartbreaking to watch and a testament of the talent of this young woman.Lakeith Steinfeld as Marcus is another excellent choice. The young actor has a cold armor around him all the time, radiating stoicness and absolute rage and
impotence all at once. Just like Jayden, his background is very moving and sad, and he gets a lot of moments that truly hit the hammer on the nail for what this movie wants to convey to us.As for Rami Malek, his role feels a bit unnecessary, as he is mostly used to represent the audience who feel absolutely baffled an shocked at the events that occur in the treatment center on a day to day basis. He does a reasonable job, and at the end of the movie, he integrates fairly well. I just think that you could have given him slightly more screentime to watch that integration really blossom.Direction:
Knowing that Destin Daniel Cretton actually has experience in the care of abused children, explains a lot regarding why this movie works so well. He knows exactly how to show the pain and psychological damage without saying anything, choosing to follow every character very closely and using very natural and heartfelt dialogue. He created nothing short of a masterpiece here.Cinematography:
The colour choices for this movie are interesting. Even at the toughest and gutwrenching scenes, the overal picture looks nice and warm and yellow. It reflects in a certain way the kind of environment that the workers want to create for the kids. Outside the treatment center, where help is less easily accessed, and the characters must figure out their problems themselves, grey tones and dark shadows are used. Handheld camera is preferred here over steadycam, to make you feel like you are in the same room with these characters when they are at their most vulnerable, and it works incredibly well. Sometimes you really feel like you are invading their moment and that you need to leave.Plot:
Some people critisized this movie for being little more than a series of moments inside the life of this treatment center, but while not entirely true, it is also kind of the point. It shows a lot of variety in terms of the problems each kid and their helpers are dealing with, adding a lot of human element to it. At the same time, we follow Grace and Mason outside of their work in their own problems and relationships, and how some of it translates itself to their work and vice versa. It never drags or becomes less engaging, only more compelling. The first and last scene are particulary well written in a way that makes everything come full circle.Editing:
While not that special, the pacing works remarkibly well in this movie thanks to the editing, and some scene transitions between strong emotional moments and a lighter tone work very well.Tone:
As previously mentioned, the approach is very human and intimate, both warm and extremely bone-chilling. How the movie can switch between these tones expertly is amazing, and nothing feels out of place. You get attached to every character and the compassion and warmth that they exert, while at the same time not losing sight of the horrible problems and tragedy that they deal with every day.Overall Concensus:
This movie is one of the most gripping and compelling experiences I have ever had. A lot of people can relate to the themes and topics in this, and the direction ensures that you are engaged as much as possible to what is happening. A short and intimate masterpiece, 8.8/10

Awesome in every way, but potentially one. And it's a huge one, which I'd very much like to be wrong about. From my experience, when you house a bunch of kids together (any kids, but especially kid with serious parent issues, some as old as 17) - it doesn't take long for things to descend into some real Lord Of The Flies territory. And often. I.e. For them to spend a hefty portion of their overflowing, youthful energy and creativity - straight torturing each other. The corresponding bureaucracy too, having a selection effect where people who genuinely, objectively care - get unceremoniously weeded out. I'll trust for now that the guys who made this film know something I don't, but if this representation of what a "taken away" kid is likely to encounter in such an institution is an uncharacteristically rosied one - I'd have to call this film extremely irresponsible. Because if not doing ones due diligence here, is likely to result in even one kid getting over-hastily thrown into what I suspect to be much more of a meat grinder - that would absolutely mangle all of this film's ample strengths.

Short Term 12 is warm, interesting and well put together. The direction was good enough to want to see another of his films. I generally enjoyed it, but found the characters a little over the top. It was as if the film's makers just repeatedly pressed the same emotional buttons the whole time. Like they did not believe we would get the character's personalities unless they were beaten into us. Critics applauded movie largely for its the frank portrayal of the marginalized lives of kids in the limbo of foster care, group homes, and other living situations. I agree that they were humanized here very well. The sad was really sad (which seems consistent with the setting), but for all its supposed grittiness and realism, the sweet was a little too sweet. I just could not get past this.(On an odd note, the time frame of the movie was unclear. At certain points it seemed that a lot of time was passing and then it was suggested that not much had.)

reviews.review_title: Tough to watch at times, but I promise it is worth it
reviews.content: I watch maybe 5 movies a year that I come out of feeling every emotion in the book, and this happens to be one of them. I really can't think of anything to say about this movie because I am still trying to process how real and great of a movie this was. This is not a should see movie, it is a MUST SEE MOVIE!
All actors in this movie nailed their part, except for you Brie.

reviews.review_title: Short Term 12 feels so real and is so underrated
reviews.content: A few months back, when I first heard of Short Term 12, I wasn't too interested in it. I saw the trailer, and I felt like it was something I'd watch someday, but not really like. I was so wrong.I haven't been to a place exactly like Short Term 12, but I have spent some time in psychiatric hospitals and rehab, and I can say, watching this film, I felt nostalgia towards being in rehab. The teens felt like people I'd met, and their reactions to things seemed so real, such as lashing out, trying to run away, swearing, crying, not being apart of group. The characters seemed like a family, and in places like that, you do sort of become a family.I have not seen another movie that showed such a realistic portrayal of this sort of place. My only real issue with this was the way Grace acted, as in telling the kids about her issues and going to Jayden's house and destroying her father's car. In reality, I couldn't see her acting out like that, but, I reminded myself that it is a movie, and more ridiculous things have happened in so many other films.Short Term 12 is a beautiful film, that really reaches out and touches the viewer's heart. For people who have spent time in places like Short Term 12, I would definitely recommend this film, even though it can easily be a trigger. It is one of the best films of 2013, with a great performance from Brie Larson.

The reviews got me, I got played. Sure, it shows how a Foster-Care Facility functions which could've been concluded in 5 minutes. The rest of it was absolute trash, No character development, No Plot or Drama just a bunch of overly zoomed-in shots on Poker faces and needless dialogues to fill in between. Sorry I can't sympathize with characters if I don't know how they feel. There are many movies that do better job depicting a disturbed childhood. What a disappointment.

I am a movie snob. I do not like to spend 2+ hours of my day or night watching a film whose characters leave me as soon as the credits roll. I watched Short Term 12 over a week ago, and the characters are still with me as vividly as if I had watched it an hour ago. I suspect it will be with me a year from now, or longer. In fact, I liked the movie so much, I am writing this review . . . my very first. Short Term 12 is, to me, above all else, a character study. This movie proves that story always matters; high-budget special effects mean nothing if not adequately supported by a good story with compelling characters. This movie has nothing in the way of special effects, but, oh, what a wonderful story with characters that are so real that I found myself forgetting that they are not real people! It actually feels, at times, like more of a documentary, though don't let that scare you off if you're not a fan of documentaries. It's a compliment that the actors were so convincing. The story centers on Grace, a counselor at a facility that serves as a temporary home for teens and preteens between foster homes . . . as best that I could ascertain. Grace and her boyfriend, Mason, do their best to be comforting, reassuring figures for the kids living there. Their job is to "keep them safe." Still, they are so much more than counselors to these kids. I will not relate the entire story, but there are a few points I feel compelled to mention. Namely, Jayden and Marcus are the characters with whom I most sympathized. Yes, Grace is the lead character and Brie Larson NAILED the role, but Marcus and Jayden both stole my heart. Many reviews relate Marcus' rap scene and Jayden's scene in which she reads her Octopus story to Grace as the most heart-wrenching moments (and they were indeed powerful), but for whatever reason, it was Jayden's reaction to the birthday cards the other kids made for her that got my eyes watery. In a masterful stroke of subtle foreshadowing, it is complemented at the end when Jayden has the cards displayed on her wall . . . it is one of the sweetest moments in film I have ever seen. Suffice it to say, I loved this little movie. If you like good character studies, this is one you cannot miss. Finally, I would be remiss if I did not mention how much I liked they way the movie begins and ends . . . with lovable, foul-mouthed Mason telling a story in front of the building and the subsequent chaotic (yet not at all surprising to Grace and Mason) "chase."

This was a super simple story that was told perfectly. Brie Larson was outstanding. There's nothing special about this movie. It feels very low budget and basic, but in the best possible way. It's true and real and touching and heartfelt. I was very surprised I enjoyed this movie as much as I did.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies I've ever seen 11/10
reviews.content: The story is so wonderful, the scenes, the actors, the naturality just perfect. If you watch it there is a big chance a tear is falling from your eye, just perfect! Forget about these high budget Blockbusters, this is so much better!
No action ,no real eye catching scenes,no mystery,no comedy,no thrills,very poorly presented film
Considering this movie is star studded I thought I'd give it a shot. I literally dozed off watching it. Nuff said.

I have never written a review on imdb but this movie made me write it. It's beautiful, emotional, heartbreaking and truly heartwarming. Was on my wishlist a long time bcoz of it's magnificent cast and the cast truly shined every actor nailed especially lakeith steinfield and kaitlyn dever and props to the director destin daniel cretton who made such a beautiful film. reviews.review_title: A good film after a Long Term
reviews.content: A modernistic cinema, which bases its grounds on simple human problems while the background is quite unique and real. It is a film of our time and era, having the intricacies of any great film attached to it.The film opens up with a scene having really high imaginative impact where Mason is describing an incident of how he shitted in his pants. Then, you are hit with another surprise element about where are they and what they do. This a language of filmmaking which has been long forgotten.Though it is not a mystery or suspense thriller, the lesser you know about the plot, the more chance you give the director to achieve what he wants to, with the audience. The thing I loved the most about the film is that it isn't centered around only one character. Because of this, you can feel why Grace is doing what she is doing and how Mason feels hurt or what the story of Octopus of Jayden means.The only downfall I felt in the film was absence of deep characterization. Of course, the character didn't do anything that was illogical or seemed pretentious (they behaved like real people would in circumstances like that), but the 'deep characterization' like in Jagten (The Hunt) could have set it apart.It was lovely film to enjoy and engage you throughout its running time, however, it gives you nothing to think about after it is over (you can say it loses you after the ending).Thank you for reading.

reviews.review_title: Heartfelt, genuine cinema.... one of the best films of 2013
reviews.content: Short term 12 took me by surprise, rarely a film comes which so much ingenuity. Set in the calmest of backgrounds the film takes you into a small world of 20 odd people and makes sure you are hooked till the end. The actors have done their bit to give the film the plaudits it very well deserves, all of them are lifelike, almost like you are watching a documentary. The background score and the setting of the film is brilliant and inspite of being so relaxed the movie is crisp.It has to be on your list among the top movies of the year along with the other slightly well known ones!

A wonderfully warm and truthful film, that resonates deeply in regards to my years working amongst people who are homeless as well as parenting fostered and adopted traumatised children. It does well to be uplifting without short-selling the pain and the trauma, the times you feel useless as you sit in the hurricane of pain in front of you and the way that awakens echoes of your own pain. 

Brie Larson's low-key, brilliant central performance shows what we'd see later down the track in Room as well as Marvel movies, that she's more than able to carry a film, and really connect us to the emotional core of the film. The supporting cast is also excellent, with special mention to Lakeith Stanfield and John Gallagher Jr.
The best filmmaking debut ever from Destin Daniel Cretton!

What is most impressive about Short Term 12 is that it never feels contrived. After reading up on director Destin Daniel Crettin (who is a new favorite of mine after this and Shang Chi), his personal history working in a group facility for teenagers is clearly felt. Having worked in a related field for most of my adult life, his screenplay is true to life - complete with its ups, downs, and the free flowing relationship residents have with staff workers. The story, while heartbreaking at times, moves gracefully and shows real empathy for its characters. It is interesting as it more focused on the staff than the residents of the group home, which is an avenue that has been rarely explored in films. While the in facility story resonated much more with me than the out of facility story concerning Grace and Mason's romantic relationship, this is a great movie.
Brie before she became Miss Marvel. Rami before he became Queen. Keith before he became LaKeith.

Director Destin Daniel Cretton really knows how to utilise his ability to not only create a compelling narrative within its story but also to make efficient use with its talented cast and strong performances that include Brie Larson.
If you don't have any problem to watched a roller coaster ride of emotions then I highly recommend you to watched this
Was looking for an emotional movie that wasn't too complicated, and this movie is spot on. Great performance by Brie Larson and a beautifully written story.

Very well done movie, the actors and the writers managed to get a full range of emotions out of me from sorrow to laughter. Watching this movie one can appreciate what a task it is to work with children (or people in general), how emotionally exhausting it is

This movie blinded me. It was a score I didn't expect.  The whole thing reminded me of bad times that I had to deal with in my youth. I couldn't STOP watching. Everything made me want to know, what happens next? Somewhat stressful during most episodes.. If you want a feel good happy ending, I really don't think you will find it in this show. You keep hoping for it!  "Are you going crazy" ? "Possibly...?" 
The ending is worth the wait.

Summary: Grace and Mason are young, empathetic supervisors at a group home in California. The couple must navigate their own romantic relationship while simultaneously navigating the struggles of running an underfunded program for kids with tough life experiences.

Takeaways: An intimate and raw depiction of why there is burnout in caregiver positions. I was shocked to read it was filmed in only 20 days!

The writing and directing of Destin Daniel Cretton demonstrates poise and heartfelt understanding. Cretton begins with an introductory story from Mason – an oft-told tale that has made its rounds within the compound -- and then eloquently finishes the film with a story from Mason that brings the story all the way around.
It's full circle but with no ending, much the way life is for these people involved in a group-home setting.

The acting in this movie makes it. Gallagher, Larson and Denver are standouts. This is a sad one, but my eyes never left the screen, it was so enthralling. Brilliant and powerful movie. It's one of the reasons why I became a counselor.

Short Term 12 portrays the complexity of child abuse, social workers, parental rights, and the legal system in which it operates. The chemistry between Grace (Brie Larson) and Mason (John Gallagher, Jr.) was a delight. Rami Malek's character, Nate, on the other hand, was a complete waste of space. I understand he's supposed to be the vessel through which we are pushed into the group home — the film begins on his first day as a volunteer — but he is so out of place and ineffective that he reminded me of one of those good-intentioned American teenagers who go to Africa to build homes, only to have the locals re-do the work at night. The intimacy of the camerawork, if at times claustrophobic, made the home feel tight and on-edge, even when engaging in something as simple as morning work group — you know, the typical seated circle where feelings are to be discussed, always to the chagrin on its circulants (word mine). I also wanted to note Kaitlyn Dever's performance as Jayden, the snarky, borderline acerbic, newcomer to the home whose story becomes central to Grace's arc. My only real gripe is why did Grace immediately make the appointment for an abortion, then tell Mason they're having a baby and accept his proposal, only to revert back to her original decision (which she then flip-flops on again)? It felt like the whole reason for the initial appointment was so she could drop the line "I already made the appointment". Was it supposed to be a trial run of some sort and she reserved her spot in case she wasn't satisfied with the results? Wherever this was, it didn't seem like abortion openings were few and far between. The tear-jerker ending was deserved and satisfying.
A sobering and emotionally interesting indie teen/young adult drama that also uplifts and warms the soul. Also features some gripping performances from most of the cast.
Somehow problematic but.. a good movie.

This is a beautiful, moving story. Brie Larson gives one of the best performances I've seen from her as Grace, the director of the home for troubled youth. Her performance is complex and three dimensional. And Kaitlyn Dever does an outstanding job as the deeply troubled teen who arrives and with whom Grace forms a deep attachment. This could have been a story full of cliches. But the characters and situations feel authentic. The dialogue feels natural and unforced. Even though there are some pretty dark themes running through the movie and, while grounded in suffering, it is ultimately inspiring and life affirming, providing the viewer with a powerful perspective on what it means to be a young person who is faced with adult neglect and abuse through their formative years. It's an, at times, heart-rending story and, at other times, a story of the power of shared vulnerability to heal.
Brilliant movie, brilliant cast.
You really get attached to the characters and the world they live in. What an excellent lovely movie
Very touching and inspiring. Amazing performances by everyone. I loved this movie!

Solid film that, despite the fact that at certain times it can become overwhelming in terms of situations occurring at the same time on the screen, it holds throughout its whole duration.

Incredibly well made. About as genuine and heartfelt as a film can hope to be. Powerhouse performances across the board. Great direction, writing, editing and cinematography! A fair argument to be made that this is truly the best picture of 2013!

An incredibly brilliant movie. "Short Term 12" is a movie EVERYONE needs to watch at least once in their lifetime. The movie is very unique and unlike any other movie that I've seen or heard of. Brie Larson (Grace), John Gallagher, Jr. (Mason), Stephanie Beatriz (Jessica), Rami Malek (Nate), Kaitlyn Dever (Jayden) & LaKeith Stanfield (Marcus) portray their characters spectacularly and all the emotion is served carefully & authentically. Many of the performances are very Oscar & Golden Globe-worthy and it is absolutely absurd that the movie nor its actors were not nominated for any major awards. From beginning to end, "Short Term 12" pulls you in and keeps you intrigued. If you haven't seen this movie, you must!
A touching, intimate, and realistic look at troubled youths that is carried by its well-written script, well-realized characters, and great performances from almost the entire cast.

One of my new favorite movies. I loved nearly every second of this. The acting is incredible, the cinematography adds a lot, the script is great, and the characters are fantastic. It's an intimate tale that sticks with you for days after you finish it.

Loving and empathetic to its characters' pain.

Destin Daniel Cretton's indie drama Short Term 12 (2013) is an emotionally devastating ordeal of such great sadness and profound catharsis with a mellow vibe. The openness of the cinematography is so freeing and feels genuine like you are watching real interactions in the daily lives of people suffering from trauma or grief. Cretton's melancholic tone makes Short Term 12 a hard watch, but it is so beautiful and rewarding. The hopeful ending is satisfying and uplifting to a degree.

Cretton takes a simple premise of a young woman, who is hiding the fact that she herself was abused by her perverted father, while she now helps those in similar situations to a reflective state. Short Term 12 sees Cretton write several realistic characters all going through pain of some kind in a neglected youth center similar to a film like Girl, Interrupted, but Short Term 12 is filmed closer to Room. Cretton's writing has no frills or fraudulence to it, his style is realism grounded in the coping process like how people actually try to recover and rehabilitate in actual life. Thus, Cretton's thoughtful dreamy direction gives Short Term 12 a truly empathetic feel alongside his authentic script. Destin Daniel Cretton is quite the writer and director.

Brie Larson is inspired as Grace. Her clear inner strength is projected outwards to aid these teenagers by using her own pain and insecurities to empower others. Larson is so moving as she brings a genuine warmth and impressive anguish in how she displays Grace's doubts. She gives such a nuanced performance in Short Term 12, that Larson was already preparing for her magnificent role in Room, wherein she pulls off an even more devastating performance. Brie Larson needs to continue her dramatic acting in the vein of Short Term 12 and Room as she is just marvelous at it.

John Gallagher Jr. is so heartwarming and patient as the sympathetic Mason. He is quite funny and endearing. His acting gives an optimistic look on all the horror around him as he tries to cope with his own girlfriend Grace's issues. Gallagher Jr. gives an excellent foil role as Mason to Larson's powerful leading lady Grace.

I must mention the standout young actress Kaitlyn Dever (Booksmart) as she is sublime as Jayden. You feel so bad for her, while liking her wise cracking teenage girl character. Dever is one of the best young actresses working in Hollywood today as Short Term 12 displayed her potential and Booksmart achieved it. She acts on the same level as Brie Larson, which is about as high of praise as I can give here.

Furthermore, LaKeith Stanfield is really gripping as Marcus. You see a deep pain as Marcus raps his frustrations, fears, and aggression against his mother out in a touching honest scene. His story is as tragic as anyone's in Short Term 12. Stanfield is outstanding as a dramatic actor. Between Short Term 12, Selma, Straight Outta Compton, War Machine, Get Out, and Sorry to Bother You, I would say that Stanfield is here to stay. His range is impressive and he continues to astonish me.

The lovely score from Joel P. West is mesmerizing and adds a serene warmth giving Short Term 12 a Summer vibe. Despite the dark subject matter and complex themes, the music in the movie is certainly beautiful.

Lastly, Rami Malek is neat as the new guy named Nate, but he's really just a glorified cameo. His supporting role is mostly a surrogate for the audience to have an ally experiencing all the anguish of Short Term 12 along with to ease our viewing session. He is very good at making specific facial expressions of shock or sorrow.

In all, Short Term 12 is a fantastic indie drama from director Destin Daniel Cretton. Brie Larson is as inspiring and engaging in Short Term 12 as she is in her more acclaimed role in Room. LaKeith Stanfield gets a cool acting debut feature film and we get a robust film to endure and enjoy.

Grace Howard (Brie Larson) is the young supervisor of Short Term 12, a group home for troubled teenagers. She lives with her long-term boyfriend and coworker, Mason (John Gallagher Jr.), but finds it difficult to open up to him emotionally. When Grace finds out she is pregnant, she schedules an appointment for an abortion; she eventually tells Mason about the pregnancy, who is overjoyed. She does not tell him she plans to have an abortion. At their facility, Grace and Mason focus their efforts on Marcus (Lakeith Stanfield), a resident who is about to turn 18 and is struggling with the prospect of leaving the facility. Meanwhile, Nate (Rami Malek) begins his first day as a supervisor at the facility. Grace bonds with Jayden (Kaitlyn Dever), a recent arrival at Short Term 12 who has a history of self-harm. Jayden distances herself from the other teenagers, as she does not intend to stay at the facility for long. When her father fails to pick her up on her birthday, she reacts violently toward the staff. After her outburst, she sits in the "cool-down room" with Grace, who shows Jayden her own scars from cutting herself. That night, Jayden leaves the facility in the middle of her birthday celebrations. Unable to force her to return, Grace follows Jayden to her father's house. After finding the house empty, they return to Short Term 12. When Jayden reads Grace a cryptic story she has written, Grace begins to suspect that Jayden was abused by her father...

"Short Term 12" premiered on March 10, 2013 at South by Southwest, where it won the Grand Jury and Audience Awards for a Narrative Feature. The film was widely acclaimed. Critics praised its realism and intimacy, with particular attention drawn to Larson's performance and Cretton's screenplay and direction. The film is considered one of the best films of 2013, appearing on several critics' year-end lists.

Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads, "Short Term 12 is an emphatic, revealing drama that pulls audiences into the perspective of neglected youths. Germain Lussier of /Film wrote of the film, "The whole thing just feels perfect or magical, a shining example of what cinema is all about", adding, "The performances are mindblowing, the writing sharp, and the direction beautiful. It's a very special movie." In Variety, critic Peter Debruge wrote, "the stunning SXSW fest winner puts the recent Park City competition lineup to shame ... this compelling human drama finds fresh energy in the inspirational-teacher genre, constantly revealing new layers to its characters." In a review for the Los Angeles Times, Kenneth Turan described Short Term 12 as "a small wonder", "a film of exceptional naturalness and empathy", and "moving and intimate", offering particular praise to the film's honesty and plausibility. Peter Bradshaw of The Guardian, on the other hand, criticized the film's credibility, describing it as "well intentioned, but somehow inauthentic" with a "too-cute-to-be-true ending".

Brie Larson will turn in great performances for a long time. If you liked Room, you'll love Short Term 12. Larson's humanity is so closely tied in her warmth and vulnerability. It's painful to think of the situations some kids call reality, but the characters' authenticity provide a semblance of guidance and comfort, even when they don't all have it for themselves. Mr. Robot's Rami Malek also delivers a solid performance as the newest staff member who realizes he may be in over his head.

To be unassuming is not always a bad thing cinematically. A film with a natural aesthetic needs to rely on its actors and scenarios to anchor it, tighten it, draw you into its world and fell for that world's inhabitants. Short Term 12 has a typically underwhelming opening, but one perhaps rife for larger metaphor.
As a bunch of camp workers stand around sharing a rather crude story, we get a sense of a very relaxed, mumblecore tone being established. They are a bunch of late twentysomethings, directionless, moping about and telling stories. It is the kind of indie film pastiche seen many time. Yet suddenly, a disturbed child rushes from an adjacent door and hurtles towards an exit. Suddenly, there is panic and shouting, the mood becomes tense. This is the essence of Short Term 12 . From the relaxed tone of mumblecore comes real shock and, occasionally, real darkness.
Yes, the camp is a camp for troubled youths. Where escape attempts are but minor worries when put in context of suicide attempts. Indeed, any plot arch that attempts to reach outside the realm of the camp almost seems futile. For instance, I'm struggling to even remember the presence of a romance between Grace (Brie Larsen) and Mason (John Gallagher Jr) after the fact, as the discussion will no doubt center so strongly on the scene involving the teens. Petty squabbles become major threats, and any attempt to get to close to troubled youths may be dangerous.
The film's universe carries the sort of consequences inherent to a war film. A rap performance in particular may leave you breathless; a scene in which the teens decorate a fellow housemates walls carries devastating weight. Yet, the film has an optimistic undercurrent, one that manifests in the viewer a possible fulfillment amidst emotional exhaustion.

Grace (Larson) works as a supervisor at a short-term group home for emotionally broken teenagers. The kids are supposed to stay there for less than a year - until the county figures out what to do with them - but, as we learn, some, like Marcus (Keith Stanfield), are there for more than three years. Grace and her three fellow counsellors have a huge job on their hands and it wouldn't be surprising if they cracked under pressure but they all seem to be able to handle each day's challenges with a heady mix of professionalism, empathy, humour, gravity and a bit of exhaustion. Grace, herself, is soft-spoken but she's not afraid to enforce the facility's rules - no closed doors, no profanity spoken, and no unauthorised leaving. Thankfully, most of the kids understand the rules and appreciate her tough love approach but there are a couple of kids who are still too deeply troubled to be able to stay on track all the time.

Grace's guarded world slowly starts to unravel when three big events hit her at the same time - she learns that she's pregnant; she receives word that her father will be released from prison; and Jayden (Kaitlyn Dever), a new charge, arrives at the home bearing emotional and physical scars that Grace seems to understand a little too well. Though she is well able to overcome the trust issues that the kids have, she can't seem to be able to tear down her own wall, particularly when it comes to her boyfriend and co-worker, Mason (John Gallagher Jr.; TV's THE NEWSROOM).

SHORT TERM 12 was written and directed by Destin Daniel Cretton, who once worked in a California facility similar to this one. His experiences there formed the basis of a short film of the same name that he wrote in university as his thesis project. It was released in 2008 to great praise. The long version of the film has been a festival darling since it premiered at the SXSW Film Festival in March 2013. There, it won both the Grand Jury and Audience awards, and 32 more awards at other festivals from Abu Dhabi to Mexico.

There are a couple of scenes in the film (Marcus' rap song and Jayden's children's story) that will absolutely break your heart but this film is far from being mawkish. All the performances are delivered with such sincerity you may just think that these actors understand abuse on a firsthand level. Larson's quiet and sensitive performance, though, really stands out in this work that is both solidly written and directed. As much as Grace would like to like to sublimate her own past, the events that surround her won't let her. Through her, the kids and even Mason, we see that while you can cover up the scars, they remain with you long after the abuse ends.

Magnificently acted if not a little slow, ST12 depicts a unique story not told before, with powerful dialogue and heartfelt intentions.

Brie Larson may have received more attention for Room, but ST12 is a far superior film in my eyes and has a handful of scenes that will have any viewer sitting quietly in their chair, their finger hovering over the pause button, in order to try and process what the movie just taught them.

A raw and heady drama that doesn't lose touch with its humanity or delve so far into the somber material that it feels like a drag. In a performance that catapulted her to greater visibility, Brie Larson plays Grace, supervisor-cum-therapist to a small houseful of troubled youths. Grace seems to know the right approach to penetrating even the sturdiest veneer, but that understanding stems from similar incidents in her own past that she's never truly addressed. It can often seem easier to show others the way than to do the same for yourself, I suppose. Surrounding Larsen is an excellent set of supporting efforts, helmed by John Gallagher Jr. as her big-hearted secret boyfriend/coworker, but the real show-stealers are the kids themselves. Each touched with a turgid, tragic set of challenges all their own, they succeed at portraying mistrust, resentment, anger, helplessness... and, strikingly, an innate sense of community. Their complexities are the keys to this story, gateway to a dark world that many of us would never dare to explore on our own. Efficient, emotional, intense but not oppressive - tension-breakers arrive in all the right moments - this was a wonderful surprise, and something that's bound to stick with me for some time.

"Short Term 12" is a powerful story of resiliency and the transformative power of love.  This genuine, honest portrayal of troubled teenagers is based on the real life experiences of director Destin Daniel Cretton.  Many of the characters and scenarios in the story are based on people that he encountered while working at a group facility.  It is a chilling dose of realism that will immediately engage your empathy toward teens that come from bad family situations.  Stylistically, the film uses just enough shakey cam to make it feel personal but not so much that it makes you sick.  Once it draws you in to its reality, there are a few inevitable tearjerker moments but it is nice to see that every drama does not have to end in the depths of depression.  There are even a few moments that will make you laugh!  My only issue with the script is the excessive language.  I agree that much of the profanity spoken by the teens in the facility is absolutely necessary to create the realism of their mental situations.  My issue is with the conversations of the workers.  A film like this needs to give the audience a break from the profanity so that we do not become desensitized.  By including f-words and s-words in every scene, they become less potent in the most powerful moments of the film.  While the film is set up for success with this profound script, it comes together through strong acting from top to bottom.  Between Brie Larson's powerhouse performances in this film and in "Room," she has established herself as the next big Hollywood actress.  She possesses the ability to harness the raw emotions from deep in her soul and portray them through her characters.  The real surprise is 16-year-old Kaitlyn Dever as the passive aggressive character Jayden.  Her spectrum of emotions ranges from subtle sarcastic facial expressions to a total mental breakdown.  The rap by Marcus (played by Keith Stanfield) is completely heartbreaking.  All of the residents of the facility perform beyond their years, and the cast is rounded out by John Gallagher, Jr. as the balance between normal and disturbed.  "Short Term 12" is not the most well-known film but it is a must for fans of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," "Girl, Interrupted," and any other drama that creates a realistic portrayal of life in an institution.

Right off the bat let me just say this, if anyone thinks that Brie Larson's Oscar for Best Actress was some kind of lucky fluke, then they need to go back and check out this movie from earlier in her career. Her performance in Short Term 12 might be even better than Room, and I think John Gallagher Jr. manages to pull off the same high quality acting. Actually all the cast is magnificent and that's impressive particularly because of how young some of these actors were at the time. The film is about life in a short-term housing facility for at-risk teenagers. As the movie progresses we see how the staff and residents manage to form bonds that provide healing and growth. This film is extraordinary. The film basically is about a group of kids who have all got something wrong in their life. Whether it be abusive parents, recent loss, mental issues or anything of the sort. They stay at Short Term 12 until they move on somewhere else. 

But although the story seems like your basic story of this ilk I am telling you it is so much more than that. On the surface, these kids and adults all seem fine but once you start to delve into their lives you realise just how much trouble they have been through. 

There are 3 stand-out characters in my mind. Brie Larson as Grace,  Kaitlyn Dever as Jaden and Keith Stanfield as Marcus. All three of these characters are masterfully portrayed by their acting counterparts and all have different problems. Grace and Jaden meet after Jaden is sent to Short Term 12 after the passing of her mother and immediately hit it off.  Both seem to find common ground in their suffering and the rapport between the two girls is glistening while you watch. There is one scene between the two. After an incident where Jaden strikes out because her Dad didn't pick her up on her birthday the two of them sit in the cool down room. Grace says to Jaden "All of the problems in the world are impossible to deal with when there is blood coming out of you." This essentially sums up the mentality of somebody in a dire situation. Many do not understand how it feels and I do not claim to but from all of the films I have seen dealing with this delicate subject I have never seen it summed up better.

Marcus' character is one that seems easy to read at first. He's the cool kid who has a problem with anybody who doesn't follow his lead but there is a scene where he opens up to one of the staff in a whole new way. He sits in his room and reads out a rap that describes his childhood. It's extremely powerful.

All in all this film is a masterpiece. I feel sad that it has taken me almost 3 years to watch it and now that I have I sense the way I look at certain situations will change. Not many films give you that kind of reaction when you finish them but this small, hipster film did just that.

There's a moment in Short Term 12, about an hour in, that feels so wildly out of place it will take your breath away. It's a scene out of any number of movies-a slasher flick, a gangster movie, the Jennifer Lopez vehicle Enough-but certainly not this tender-hearted drama about struggling teenagers and the two formerly-struggling teenagers turned barely-keeping-it-together adults who take care of them. And just when you think Short Term 12 has finally fallen off the tightrope it so expertly navigated for that first hour, a well-placed quip and, shortly thereafter, an emotionally devastating revelation bring it back to a place of unequivocal brilliance.

That's the film in a nutshell. It toes so many lines-it's at times almost too mawkish, frenetic, and under-detailed. But it improbably manages to avoid being any of those things. It is, instead, parts an onion-like character piece and a penetrating coming-of-age drama that manages to sprinkle in just enough beneath-the-pain smiles to make the exercise enjoyable. Simply put, it's a once-in-a-blue-moon movie that's sure to rank among my very favorites this year.

The film's title refers to the home for at-risk teens that Grace (Brie Larson) and Mason (John Gallagher Jr.) work at. Both are great at jobs they love, and both are lucky to have found love on the job. Yes, Grace and Mason are together. It's not a well-kept secret, but they aren't trying to keep it a secret. Grace, however, is keeping a secret from Mason; she's pregnant.

While she contemplates having an abortion (it'd be her second) or keeping it, a new girl arrives at Short Term 12. Jayden (Kaitlyn Dever) has been in and out of homes like this her whole life; she knows the rules. Grace is taken with this girl almost immediately, and she's able to connect with Jayden in a way no one-including her father-has been able to. But there's a reason she's here, and as things start to go south with Jayden, so they do with Grace. She has some tendencies, and as various pressures in her personal life threaten to boil over, those tendencies begin to show.

One must start with Larson. Acting this good just doesn't happen very often. It brings to mind Elizabeth Olsen's breakout turn in Martha Marcy May Marlene in 2011, if not substantially than at least in the sense that it should make the young actress a star. Larson, of course, isn't a total stranger. She was the romantic lead in 21 Jump Street. She also popped up in The Spectacular Now and Rampart, but to lead a film as good as Short Term 12 and as well as she does is, well, pretty huge and monumentally impressive.

What's great about the performance is what's also great about writer/director Destin Cretton's top-notch screenplay. The film opens with a monologue-one of several laugh-out-loud funny monologues from John Gallagher Jr., who's also terrific in the film-and while it's being told, we see Grace as this put-together good samaritan. Along the way, it's little details-the way she nervously picks her skin, her almost obsessive protectiveness over Jayden-that hint at a dark past. She's not an open person, however, so there's a nagging mystery at the heart of the film. It never suffocates us-character very much comes first in Short Term 12-but we're fed just enough story to remain satisfied throughout.

I really adore Short Term 12 for so many reasons-including its deliberately unpolished look-and it's a little tricky to define why other than to say I've seen films like this many times that fail, moderately or miserably. Not so with Cretton's feature (based on a short he directed in 2008). It's an utterly delightful experience. Its subject matter isn't joyful, but you'll find joy instead in the perfect way it all comes together.

Sure, sometimes there is something special about a person and you feel oddly connected to them... but this is a movie. Sometimes a movie that on the surface may seem small in both scale and scope has much more to say than anyone gave it credit for until they themselves have seen it. Destin Cretton's feature debut Short Term 12 is one of those films whose synopsis does not give it credit for what it broaches in its short 90 minute running time.

Coming out of nowhere and striking a chord with audiences the world over Short Term 12 is a fantastically written and observant film that has a lot to say about both disconnected youth and those whose lives have been affected by sometimes unspeakable trauma. Cretton has a deft touch both in his screen writing and in his gritty hand-held filming approach and the two mould together to paint an emotionally driven portrait of those in the "limbo" house between broken home and new foster accommodation. There are some striking scenes in the film namely a heartbreaking rap from Marcus (Stanfield) a boy who has clearly experienced much heartbreak or two bookend scenes played out with dialogue chronicling adventures of the homes residents. These moments in the film showcase Cretton as a talent to watch just like the films leading lady Brie Larson.

Small films like Short Term 12 have been a breeding ground for break out performances for years now, with those looking to break into a tough industry choosing tough roles to show off their wares. Brie Larson here in her role as conflicted and inwardly troubled worker Grace stamps herself as an actress capable of both pure heartrending emotion and an equal talent at comedic timing and lovable charm, no doubt a few tricks were learned from her time in praised TV show The United States of Tara and supporting roles in films such as 21 Jump Street and Don Jon. It's a pleasure to see an actress grow before your eyes as Larson does and she is ably supported by an impressive adult cast and a cast of young adults that are led by Justified's impressive young actress Kaitlyn Dever.

Short Term 12 is as stated a small film that deals with big issues and deals with them in a way that is both confronting yet in a manner that seems just right. It's a film brimming with heart and personality and a film that could stand equal to many more high profile films of last year. I personally can't wait to see where both Larson and Cretton go to next.

This is a great example of the modern American independent film at its best: telling straightforward, emotionally affecting stories about the sorts of people big studio movies would never think to make a movie about. It doesn't have any major stars (though Brie Larson seems on her way to becoming one) or anything technically remarkable about it, but it's got everything it needs to be powerfully moving.

The story follows Grace (Larson), a young woman who works at a short-term care home for at-risk teenagers. She's a humble and compassionate presence to her young charges, but we slowly learn that she's got some serious damage of her own. In following her story, the movie also provides significant glimpses into the life of her boyfriend, who also works at the home, and several of the kids she takes care of. There are other movies out there in which a teacher or social worker tries to help troubled youths (the gratingly fake Half Nelson and the overblown and ridiculous Precious come to mind), but few if any of them feel as honest and real as this one. There isn't that much more than that to say, really. This is a great movie in a very simple and straightforward way. It's genuinely compassionate for its characters' problems and doesn't provide easy or fake solutions. And the excellent closing scene illustrates very clearly how life just goes on. I strongly recommend it.

There are a short list of films that for whatever reason strike a emotional nerve with me.  They don't necessarily have to be about something that I personally identify with, but they do such an effective job at pulling me into their world and their characters and their trials that I feel like, just by watching, I'm toeing emotional eggshells.  Short Term 12 is one of those films.

The movie focuses on a group of people who supervise a home for foster kids who are considered "at-risk".  The film opens with the workers on a break of sorts, chatting it up and enjoying themselves.  It's funny, but it's also a great way to acclimate the audience with these very real people who have a hell of a job.  The head of this group, Grace, is played to perfection by the charismatic Brie Larson.  She hammed it up for cameras as Envy Adams in Scott Pilgrim vs. The World, but here you'll find a much more real persona.  People talk of a lack of heroines in films and while I know they're mostly referring to those of the action variety, Grace is inspiring in a very different capacity.  She's struggling to deal with her own shoddy past and how that's fucked up her life, all while helping teenagers try to deal with their own shit.

If the movie sounds like it deals with some serious subject matter, that's because it does.  Don't let that scare you away though because thankfully the film knows when to lighten the tone so the whole ordeal doesn't go "Requiem for a Dream" on ya.  A large source of the amusement comes from supporting character Mason, Grace's love interest.  He also works with the troubled teens and actor John Gallagher Jr. keeps Mason from becoming a caricature.  He's a funny guy, but the kind that's real-world.  You wouldn't mind sitting down and having a drink with the man.  And then there's the kids themselves, and each one walks and talks with an aura of authenticity.  There's not a scene or a moment you'll question.

As you can see, I've talked mostly about the characters of this story.  The plot threads weave themselves in and out of this foster care program, but what you'll remember is the characters these people portray.  Life can be hard, especially for a teenager.  When they don't have a family who can help guide them, these people in foster care programs are more than just names and faces; they ARE family.  This film has a lot of heart and it often hurts but I'm happy to say that I found a very uplifting message come the film's close.

Review In A Nutshell:

Short Term 12 shares a similar feel as Laurent Cantet's The Class. It follows a protagonist, who acts as a guide for children or young adults in order to prepare or shelter them from the real world. The prime difference between the two films is that both are caring for two different aspects of a person's life; The Class on education and wisdom, while Short Term 12 on emotional and physical trauma. The Class swept me away due to its empathetic and sympathetic protagonist and featuring problems that were a genuine reflection of our own classrooms. Short Term 12 certainly hits the mark in delivering effective and authentic drama, but it didn't "move" me as much when watching it.

The film does not feature a core complication for the audience to dwell on, therefore it does not establish any sort of measurable goal. Instead, Short Term 12 is a character-study, under the facade of a documentary style, as it simply follows the life Grace and exploring the relationships that she is trying to maintain within and outside the residential facility. The film allows us to see the connections she has with her profession and how that and her personal history build and shape her relationships. Grace displays a sense of empathy towards the young residents, as a way to make them feel comfortable; her aim is to build a shield for them, so they won't have to suffer from the evil that lurks outside. Though she acts as a mentor to these people, she herself is not as composed and balanced as she displays herself to be; there are some demons that are feeding from her soul, and with each problem that surface, it becomes harder and harder for her to survive in her profession, especially in an emotional level.

The film's camera-work utilises a hand-held approach in order to achieve that intimate documentary feel that Destin Daniel Cretton, the director, requires to tell this story. It creates this feeling, like as if the audience was a spectating caretaker herself, following and monitoring Grace; similar to what she and her co-workers does when a person escapes from their facility.

Short Term 12 wouldn't have been the emotional and intimate ride that it is, if it weren't for Brie Larson's performance. Larson was able to meet the demands that were needed in making this role come off as sophisticated and most importantly, real. Her role is the type that would normally cry out to its audience for sympathy, but she does not force it down our throats; the timing and tone that she delivers her dialogue makes her character's own personal story feel natural and convincing.

Short Term 12 is drama at its purest form. The film did not require screaming matches or physical confrontation to create tension and it showcases a marvellous performance from Brie Larson. If this does not lead her to more varied and sophisticated roles, then cinema and its audience are missing out on a wonderful thing.

A delicate and complex character study that never romanticizes what it wants so say, being instead very down to earth in its approach to show us how an underprivileged childhood can create emotionally fractured adults whose uncured issues won't simply go away with time.

The foster care system is the most flawed institution in the United States, which is disheartening as many of the children in said system deal with abuse, loneliness, and mental health issues. "Short Term 12" comprises everyday goings on of a facility for kids who live between homes and the street, and the workers who help them. At the crux of the film is Grace (Larson) who leads the facility's workers and helps kids while also dealing with her own life. It's really quite sweet that Grace and her boyfriend Mason (Gallagher) have fragmented childhoods, and so they have to (rather than want to) help ease the pain of these children and the problems they face. In comparison is a college worker who would like to help, but doesn't know where to start. The performances from the child actors in this film are nothing short of astounding. Brie Larson commands complete presence onscreen, as Grace, a multi-faceted basket case who is always trying to do better, but inevitably has to fight her demons. This is a really sweet, funny, heartfelt film dealing with big issues in a sensitive and thoughtful way, which makes it highly recommendable.
